speaker: Doctor
text: What specific symptoms is the newborn experiencing, and when did they first appear?

speaker: Patient
text: I'm having trouble breathing, and it started about two hours after I was born. I also make a grunting sound and my chest seems to be pulling in. My hands and feet look a bit blue too.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any complications during the delivery or any issues with the mother's health during pregnancy?

speaker: Patient
text: There weren't any complications during delivery, and my mom had a normal pregnancy until I was born early. She didn't mention any health issues.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in the newborn's feeding patterns or activity level since birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't really been able to feed well since I was born. I feel too tired and uncomfortable to eat much.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you observed any signs of nasal flaring or retractions in the newborn while breathing?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I can see that my chest is pulling in a lot when I breathe, and I think my nose is flaring too. It feels like I'm working really hard to get air.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any abnormal sounds when the newborn breathes, such as wheezing or stridor?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't heard any wheezing or stridor, but I do make a grunting sound when I breathe. It feels like I'm struggling to get enough air.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any signs of meconium-stained amniotic fluid during delivery?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't know about the amniotic fluid since I wasn't aware of that during delivery. But I can tell you that I was born early and have been having a hard time breathing since then.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any signs of cyanosis or changes in skin color apart from the blue hands and feet?

speaker: Patient
text: I've noticed that my hands and feet are blue, but I haven't seen any other changes in my skin color. My face looks normal, but I feel really uncomfortable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any temperature changes, such as feeling unusually hot or cold since birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't really felt hot or cold, but I do feel a bit clammy. My body just feels off, and I'm not very comfortable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any signs of respiratory distress in the newborn, such as rapid breathing or a decreased level of consciousness?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I've been breathing really fast, and it feels like I'm working hard to get enough air. I don't feel sleepy, but I do feel very tired and uncomfortable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any signs of heart murmurs or abnormal heart rates observed by the medical team?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any heart murmurs or anything unusual about my heartbeat. I just feel really tired and struggle to breathe.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have any blood tests been performed to check for infection or other abnormalities?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't know if any blood tests have been done. I just feel really weak and uncomfortable, and I'm focused on trying to breathe better.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any signs of abdominal distension or difficulty with bowel movements in the newborn?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any problems with my tummy or bowel movements. I mostly just feel really tired and have a hard time breathing.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any signs of jaundice or yellowing of the skin or eyes since birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't seen any yellowing of my skin or eyes. My color seems normal apart from my blue hands and feet. I just feel really uncomfortable and tired.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any signs of fluid retention or swelling in the newborn's body?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any swelling or fluid retention anywhere on my body. I just feel really tired and have a hard time breathing.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have there been any signs of a family history of respiratory issues or congenital heart defects?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't know about my family's medical history since I'm just a newborn. I haven't been able to ask anyone about it.

speaker: Doctor
text: What is the newborn's current heart rate and oxygen saturation level?

speaker: Patient
text: I can't really tell you my heart rate or oxygen levels since I'm just a newborn. I just know that I'm having a tough time breathing and feel really tired.

speaker: Doctor
text: What is the current oxygen saturation level measured by the medical team?

speaker: Patient
text: I can't see the numbers myself, but I know they said something about my oxygen levels not being where they should be. I'm just really struggling to breathe and feel very tired.

speaker: Doctor
text: REQUEST TEST: Arterial_Blood_Gas.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: pH: 7.30 (slightly acidic), PaCO2: 50 mmHg (elevated), PaO2: 60 mmHg (reduced), HCO3-: 24 mEq/L

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on the results, it appears that there is significant respiratory distress with hypoxemia and hypercapnia. Have there been any signs of respiratory infections or other illnesses in the newborn's immediate environment?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't been around anyone who is sick, and I don't think there are any infections in my environment. I just feel really weak and have a hard time breathing.

speaker: Doctor
text: DIAGNOSIS READY: Neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome (NRDS) due to surfactant deficiency.
